botanical_details.genus: Pyrus are deciduous trees or shrubs with oval leaves and scented white flowers in spring, followed by green or brown fruits, edible in some species

how_to_grow.cultivation: Suitable for all trained forms. Prefers a deep, fertile, moist but well-drained, neutral soil in a sheltered, warm, sunny position. Will not thrive on very acid soils, shallow chalk soils or with shade for more than half the day
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by grafting or budding onto a rootstock for fruit. Quince rootstocks are usually used. Fruit grown from pips will not resemble the parent
how_to_grow.pruning: Regular pruning required; a spur bearer. Prune according to form: cordons, espaliers and pruning established fans. Can also be grown as standards or spindlebushes. For further guidance see: pruning new pear trees, summer pear pruning, winter pear pruning, renovating pear trees
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by aphids, caterpillars, codling moth and pear blister mite
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by pear scab, blossom wilt, brown rot, fireblight and pear rust
